content.text: Blakely and Dustin Ball’s best Christmas gift last year, their daughter Brighton, was a long time coming.
They navigated a four-year struggle with infertility, seeking answers that multiple doctors couldn't provide until consulting with Rejoice Fertility.

In this episode of our Hope, Faith, & Infertility podcast, learn how this couple’s faith sustained them through the emotional rollercoaster of uncertainties, treatments, and setbacks. Here's the link:

content.text: A brain tumor first led to RJ & Lacie’s infertility, but their journey was just beginning. Years of heartbreak and no babies followed. They were down to their last embryo- and it didn’t look good.
But they kept faith in an underdog- and are glad they did!

Find out the dramatic conclusion to their journey, and how God gave them the peace they needed to persevere along the way, in this episode of our podcast 'Hope, Faith, & Infertility.' The link is below:
Share, rate, review, and subscribe to 'Hope, Faith, & Infertility' wherever you listen to podcasts.

content.text: “God is not above demolishing your hopes and dreams.” It’s a quote Eric Knox has not only uttered but lived.

An accident when he was a teenager left Eric permanently paralyzed. He wasn’t sure he could have children, or even whether he wanted to. But his wife Kendra felt the call to motherhood. And together, through Mini-Stim IVF, they discovered there is hope for spinal cord victims to become biological parents. They also learned that when God demolishes your dreams (and, in Eric’s case, fears as well), He’s ultimately bringing blessing, not devastation.
Eric & Kendra (and their daughter Eliana!) share their story in this episode of Hope, Faith, & Infertility. Here's the link:
Please rate, review, and subscribe wherever you listen to podcasts.
A full transcript is below (Please note this transcript was done by AI and may contain factual & grammatical errors):

Well, there is hope for people who have spinal cord injuries when it comes to having children, and my guests today are living proof. Eric and Kendra Knox are with me here on hope, faith and Infertility, a podcast of Southeastern fertility in Knoxville, Tennessee. And their story is full of hope, encouragement, and definitely faith. So let's start here. Eric, we've had your wife on before. We haven't had you on before. I'm glad to have both of you here. So tell me about your spinal cord injury, how it happened and how it changed your life.

Yeah, I was 15 years old and I was with a bunch of friends. We were in a big field that it was actually dug out for making a lake, but there had been no rain. And so were out there, boys being boys, doing donuts and throwing a ton of dust in the air and all that kind of fun stuff. And I was with a friend of mine riding shotgun, and we flipped the truck. It threw me out of the passenger side window, and then the truck rolled over me and you could imagine it was a pretty hard hit. So I'm just happy to be alive, really. But, yeah, I was conscious through the whole thing. It rolled over me right at the belly button area and so immediately just paralyzed me from the waist down or, well, from the belly button down.

And man, I actually leaned up like I was going to walk away from it. Like I said, I was fully conscious. I wasn't in any pain or anything like that. But I just realized that I couldn't move my legs. And everyone got pretty freaked out after that and we called an ambulance and it wasn't anything immediately that I thought was going to define the rest of my life. I thought it was going to be, I would get stuff back and then get back to life as usual, but that was not the case. But I've had a spinal cord injury, I'm a T ten paraplegic and have been so now for about 20 years.
Wow, interesting. You do remember it all. You weren't unconscious during this and you don't remember any pain?

There was no pain immediately. Initially, it was that huge surge of adrenaline that happeNed. I remember that. You ever get hit in the face with something and there's that immediately spike of adrenaline, but then, you know, like 5 seconds later you're waiting. You're like, man, it's about to start hurting. I know it. And I remember waiting for that pain to come, and it just didn't come. And because it cut off all sensation below the entry level, so I wasn't able to feel it. But after probably a couple of hours, I started realizing that my back was starting to ache, in which case it had been completely broken. I mean, the spine was just at about a 45 degree angle from where it was supposed to be.
And so they had to do a stabilization surgery and put rods and nuts and bolts and all that type of stuff.
I don't even know. I mean, it was several hours. The doctor told me that he was picking bone fragments out for several hours after that. It was a pretty traumatic event, but I'm happy to be here.

Yeah, absolutely. And your wife is great. I mean, God has really blessed you guys, and we'll talk about your daughter very soon, too. She's a huge reason that you're here. When you guys met Kendra, you said having kids. I mean, not the first meeting, but I mean, early on in your relationship, you had made it clear to Eric that having kids was obviously, you know, having this sort of an injury really complicates things. So you did run into a lot of roadblocks, as a lot of couples will. How discouraging was that for each of you?

Yeah. Well, just to clarify, I was open to if God would build our family a different way through adoption or I knew that your injury level, because you were very honest from the beginning that we didn't know. It was a big question mark about if kids would be possible and if they were, there was a decent chance that we would need fertility treatments. Just as you're evaluating a life partner and you're like, what are the things that I feel called to? I felt like I'm called to be a mom. That's something in my heart that I don't think is going to go away. So just Having some initial conversations where you were not all on board about kids.
So you weren't sure you wanted to have kids?

No. Well, I have a disability, and I also work with kids who have disabilities, and I see the weight that carries on the parents. And I was just like, you know, a surefire way to get around that is to just not have kids. And I had two nieces at the time. Love them to death. But I just thought, man, having kids is going to be a big hassle, and I have a disability, so it's going to even be even more of a difficulty. And I was just like, you know what? Life is just going to be a lot easier if we just don't have kids, and I don't really care to have them. And a lot of that was some fear of, like, man, nobody wants to have a kid with a disability.
And parenting from a wheelchair is scary.

Yeah. In the end of it, too, you're thinking, man, what if? I don't know how many times I've seen a kid run out to the road and a parent quickly chase them down, and I'm like, I can't do that. I can get to them in some situations, but if that kid, something happens to them because of, I wasn't able to get there quick enough. Am I ever going to be able to forgive myself? I don't know. And really just like, the root of it was a lot of fear. And I just knew. I just kept coming back to like, man, the way around that is just don't have kids and I'll be just fine.

By the way, that line of thinking does make a lot of sense. I mean, I get it. It's very logical, very much linear thinking. How did the two of you navigate this? Because the problem is that you're dating a young woman who's like, I am definitely called to be a mom. There's no doubt about that. So how did you navigate this? And if there weren't, please tell me. But were there deep conversations with God about this? I'm interested in hearing all that.

Oh, absolutely. I mean, several deep conversations about that. But she made it clear, like, I am going to be a mother. That's something that she was definitely called to, was in her heart, and was like you said, it was a non negotiable thing. And so I had to really revisit the idea of having kids when I.

Was, at this point, ready to cut and run, because I was know, I want somebody who not just wants kids, but has a passion for being a father and being a leader in the home and all of these things that are on my list. And it really was the Holy Spirit who told me to just be still and wait and allow God to work on Eric's heart. And I just started praying, and I'm surprised I didn't.

Oh, I am too. Look, when I told her, when the whole thing of kids came up and I was like, you know, I don't really want kids. I mean, I saw it in her eyes immediately was like, oh, gosh, this is the deal breaker. And I was like, man, I just lost her.

We felt like God led us to enter a relationship, and so there's this moment where you're like, god, you've led us this far. And Eric was the first real, know, committed dating person that I'd ever had in my life. And so, like, this whole history of waiting for hi, baby. And so when he's on the scene, I'm like, God wouldn't lead us this far and then just leave us. So anyways, were talking one day and I think I brought up the fear thing you did a little bit and was like, Eric, just, is there any way that you're not trusting God? I was like, have you prayed and asked God if you're called to be a dad? And I really felt like there was something holding him back.

And I remember that you shared with me about the disability, you said, and you just teared up and you were like, I can't be the dad that goes in the backyard and throws a baseball around with my kids. What does that even look like? And I remember looking at you and telling you that as a parent, the most important thing for me isn't that my husband can go play ball with them in the backyard, but that he has a heart that is so in love with Jesus. And just as a dad that any kids that would come into our family would see that you had gone to the pit to the worst day possible. And somehow God's grace was enough to get you through it.

And I was like, that's the man that I want to be the father of my children, however God brings them in. And I knew from the beginning he's going to be good at it. We just had to get you to believe it, too.
And was that where your heart was, Eric? I mean, basically you were following after Christ hard, but there was just this fear lodged in you for those legitimate reasons.

Absolutely. Yeah. At the heart of it was, again, a human being taking power into his own hands, not trusting the father with what he knows is best. And I did. I took that power into my own hands and I said, however much I love God, you can't make me have kids. I'm going to just not do it and I'll skirt this whole issue and still serve you. But at the heart of that was me and my ability to take control of this situation. And I wasn't trusting him because I had some fears there. I can't go in the back and play baseball with the kids and stuff like that. It's going to be different, though. Just about anything that I want to do, I can make a way to do it, but it's just very different.

But then having to figure out how to incorporate kids into that is going to be a whole nother issue, which is just a lot of it was that. But also just. I don't know. I had a fear that really wasn't based in logic, where I just always felt like, man, if I have a kid, they're going to end up having a disability, too, and how do I.

Yeah, I got to take care of me and my disability and this kid, and it's just going to be too much. And so that was just one of those illogical fears. Like, there's no scientific evidence that suggests that people with disabilities are at increased risk of having kids with disabilities.
And, of course, you know that if you did have a kid with a disability, God would give you the strength to get through it. Now, that fear of, what does this look like? Yeah.

I will say this. We did come full circle, because by the time I said I do, you had opened your heart to that idea, and it still was a process. I think when we got married were like, okay, I'm on board. Like, God has dealt with me on this. I'm on board for kids, but wait a year to get started. And then it was like, so we got married, and I was like, okay, we're a little older in life, so I thought, like, okay, the clock is ticking. Don't wait too long here. But it was just a couple of months in when you came to me, and you were like, you know, I was praying, and I don't know that I ever prayed and asked God about what is his timing for our family?
And because we knew that it might take a lot longer for us to figure out God's plan, we decided to go ahead and start on that journey.
And how long have you guys been married now?
Bragging rights. Once you get to five years, right?

Yeah. Before five years, everybody be like, you're newlywed. Hey, we got a tiny little bit of street credit right now. We've been together for five years. We've not even mentioned the word divorce. I feel like we're doing all right.

Yeah, no, that's great. I love hearing it. And when you did pursue parenthood, and we'll bring your daughter, Eliana, on here in just a few minutes. She's adorable. We've had a chance to meet her, which is awesome. So we'll see her soon. But your road was. We don't have to go into it all, but it's like, there were a lot of roadblocks, a lot of steps, a lot of things you tried, a lot of heartbreak. So it probably was a very good thing that you started early. On. There may be a lesson there. You eventually did find Southeastern fertility, and it was really the minimal stimulation, IVF, mini stem, IVF for short, that was compelling. Why did that seem appealing to the two of you?

Well, we had talked about, like, in our pursuit to have children, we're not going to put our faith and our beliefs aside just because we do have this passion. And when we looked at some of the typical IVF protocols, there's often a lot of embryos that are created with no plan for how to use them, and we believe life begins at conception. So were like, not having a plan is not an option for us, and we can't set aside our pro life beliefs just because we want this child. So we initially thought IVF was just off the table in general, because we didn't know a whole lot about the options and ways of doing it. And so we kind of pursued some other means.

And then when we kind of came to a halt at one point where were told, your last chance is IVF, I really had to deal on my heart at that point with, like, all right, is this the end of our biological child journey? And is God enough for me if we're called to this? But I was listening to a podcast, and somebody mentioned mini IVF, which I'd never heard of, and a lot of clinics don't talk about it. It's honestly hard to find clinics that offer it, and I'm sure you know, but for anybody that's listening, it's an approach that creates a lot fewer embryos. And you could do natural cycle where you just create one, or you could try to transfer just two or three. And what I gathered from Southeastern was that they were a pro life organization.

You're a non discard facility, which immediately gave a lot of peace to us, because when you don't know the medical world, it's hard to have that trust of, like, what exactly are you doing? And break it down to our level so that we really understand.

Yeah, well, for one thing, I'm in the medical field, and so I already know when you're talking to patients, you're attempting to give informed consent in a lot of different areas, but this individual doesn't have a medical background at all. It's hard to really explain 100% exactly what this consent is, what you're consenting to, and what all the background stuff is. And I know sometimes if you have a doctor who, if there's an emergency situation, he's going to perform whatever he has to do, and there's not always a great amount of time to go and explain to someone informed consent and then come back and do what is in best interest. So we wanted someone who, for all of those reasons, someone who is operating with a worldview of having Life is sacred. Yeah, life is sacred. It begins at conception.

You have a Christian background of some sort, is what I would really love so that we don't have to worry about you in those behind the scenes efforts, is that we always know that you're operating with a worldview that says, this life is, even though it is an embryo right now, it's a human life, and I value it. And that's what we wanted.

We also love that Southeastern is partners with the NEDC. And so weren't sure if mini IVF was going to work for us, and we liked the idea of already being familiar with this clinic. So if the Lord leads us to Snowflake adoption, that we know the people. And it seemed like a nice fit to have that feature as well, even though it was 6 hours away from us in Knoxville.

Yeah, you guys are all the way in Mississippi, and we're in Knoxville. Whether you do Southeastern fertility or the National Embryo Donation center, each place, you're going to have to travel here to Knoxville. That's the one thing that's different. But you guys were willing to do it. So glad that you did. And I know we had Kendra on a couple of years ago, and the success was not immediate. Even here with us, it was not easy. Did you ever doubt that it would actually work, that God would actually grant you a biological child, even through a careful fertility procedure like mini Stem IVF?

Yeah. Well, I went into it not feeling that God had promised me anything. And I loved that. Your clinic was very honest about, like, these are the chances, and it's difficult to not get almost superstitious about chances and looking at percentages, and you get to the point where you just have to reason in your heart and say, God's going to do what God wants to do, and we need to be faithful if we feel him calling us to do a procedure. And what I did struggle with was we felt a lot of peace about trying it. We went, I think it was end of July into August and did our first cycle, and we both had really good feelings about it. We had a piece and ended up having a chemical pregnancy and super early miscarriage.

And so dealing with that, like, wow, there were two little embryos transferred, and were ready to welcome those kids into our lives and homes. And so mentally having to understand, I felt that God called us to this. So then why did it end this way? And the Lord really led me into a lot of the Psalms and just knowing that God is good, it sounds cliche, but it really is the Gospel. It is.
Whatever you're going through now, someday your life will be great.

Yeah. And you look at David and he's looking at his enemies, and he's like, why are they flourishing? And I'm over here hiding in a cave, and I think we kind of felt like we're honoring you, Lord, in every area of our life. And why are these people getting pregnant and having babies? And if you look at, I think it's Psalm 72, David, when he complains about his enemies, he has this heart check in the middle of the chapter. And then he says, and then I came into the house of God, and it's like everything changes. And he realizes who God is and that he needs to regret his perspective. It was rough those first couple of days. You were a little salty at God for a minute.

Oh, yeah. For having a spinal cord injury from the age of 15. At 15, your hopes and dreams are very different. You got all kinds of different stuff going, rolling around in your noggin. And I already know and have 100% experience God is not above demolishing your hopes and dreams because they don't factor into his plan for your life.
He has good plans. He has good than your plan.

They're different than yours. And you're like, man, I know he's placed something in my wife that she has a nurturing motherliness about. And he had already, through prayer and time together and discussions with Kendra, had removed this seed of fear in my life and had moved me towards fatherhood. And I'm like, all right, you brought us here. Yeah, you took us right here, man. Like, what's your deal? And then you're like, okay, I've got to set aside my hopes and dreams of what I think our future is going to be like. And I told her, I was like, maybe we're supposed to be in our church. We're going to be moms and dads of kids who don't have great moms and dads in the church. You know what I mean? Sometimes you have to be kind of, what would you call it?

Kind of, yeah, kind of like a supplementary type parental figure to a person who said that. Because I'm like, there's a lot of single moms in churches that they don't have dads, and there's some who, they have moms, but they're not great moms. And so maybe that's what we're supposed to do is kind of be like supplemental parents to kids in our church. I don't know.

Again, the Holy Spirit was so good because he tells me this, and I'm, like, freaking out because, no, I'm not done trying. I really am. Not. Initially, you're just grieving. But I think it was like, by the next day, I was like, I don't think I had to. The Holy Spirit just kept me quiet. And it was just, I think, a week or two later, and you came to me on your own, and you were like, you know what? I think maybe we should try this one more time. And this time, when we tried, I approached the first time with a whole lot of positivity and peace, just to show you that our emotions mean nothing as far as success.

Yes, I approached the second trial with just dread and knowing this is not going to work, but I have to do it just to have peace in my mind. And, yeah, it was successful and shocked us both. I think were both thinking, like, this is kind of it. I don't know that we could endure another disappointment.

Well, I love it, and so many key points there, but a couple that are just really good to camp out on. Before we talk about Eliana, I want to underscore one. Emotions in this particular realm don't necessarily correlate to success. People need to know that. And I've talked, by the way, with a lot of people who were just like you, who came in, whether it's embryo adoption or IVF or whatever, they came in super pumped for the first One. It didn't work. They get down and then they temper the expectations, maybe even feel a little bit negative the second time around, and.
That'S when it gets hurt again. So I'm not going to hope this time.

Yes, people do that. And you know what? They still have success. So, man, such an important point. And I also really liked what you said, Eric. Very memorable. God is not above demolishing your hopes and dreams. And that doesn't sound encouraging to people as believers, we don't want to hear that. But there's a song that says, you thought God was an architect. Now, you know, he's really like a pipe bomb ready to blow. And that is the truth. And it just reminds me that his dreams and plans for our lives are better than our dreams and plans for our lives. And as a Christian, it may take decades, but you have to get to that point. And that's where you, at 15 years old, I guarantee you didn't see yourself in this situation.
No. All of those hopes and dreams that I had were not built on the foundation of Christ. They were built on the very wrong foundation, really?

And I was just going to say something that I wanted to add is a lot of times we mistake. In the world of Christianity, we mistake positivity for faith. Those are not like, man, if I believe hard enough, faith isn't believing something hard enough, even if it is like having kids is a very biblical thing. But just because you believe hard enough that it's going to happen, that's not faith. Our faith is in Christ alone and his accomplishment and what his will for our life is, which we don't know what it is exactly. We don't know if it's going to be to have no kids. One, two, three, who knows? And so our faith is in whatever it is that he has for us.
Just to balance all of that out. The goodness of God is very real.

And it's different than what we want. But for any believer who trusts in him, on the worst day, when we're dealing with finding out about the miscarriage, God's peace was there through that. And I don't know how unbelievers go through things like that without him. And there were so many moments throughout our whole journey that God gave us little, just glimmers of hope and who he is to kind of. Are you waving?

I was going to say, and, yes, he does. He gives you those windows to help keep you going. So he's good in that respect. But for those of you who are watching the video version, you're seeing this beautiful little 16 month old, Eliana, who is their daughter, the result of their second transfer. And so we're going to talk about her a little bit again, beautiful little girl and a dream come true for you guys. So I want to hear about her. What's she like, and how has she changed your lives?

She's a Spitfire. Her name, first of all, Eliana Joy means God has answered because we had so many people praying for us, and joy because she brought us so much joy. And when were praying over her, when she was in the womb, I remember praying. We both got the word gentleness when were praying separately. Yeah, God's just calling us. I was praying the fruit of the spirit over my little tummy, and I prayed about gentleness, and I got three kicks, and it was the first time I felt her kick and I just thought, oh, the Lord's going to give us the most gentle child ever. It's a sign.

And I was praying, too, and I was like, I don't know why, but I just feel like she's going to be a gentle soul. It was like that just resonated with me for some reason. And again, it was a feeling, so nothing that I can count on. But it was Od that both of us separately got the word gentle.

Well, and there's a scripture that says that a woman should have a gentle and quiet spirit, which is a great worth in sight. And I love that, because in today's culture, there's a lot of women that, of course, we have a voice, but you don't have to scream and shout and be rude. I wanted her to have a feminine spirit and the spirit that God created for her. And so we're praying gentleness. And, of course, this little one, she is a daredevil. She is one of the strongest little toddlers you have ever made. So I think God was preparing us. Okay, go ahead and start praying for gentleness.

It was not an innate gentleness inside of her that God, maybe he was speaking to us, that. You guys are going to have to cultivate gentleness, this one, because she's not coming pre programmed with it. Keep that in the forefront of your mind.

It's a fruit of the spirit. And until she has the opportunity to choose Christ, that's how gentleness is being formed and created in her. But I will say she is one of the most determined little ones. And our prayer for her is, because I think we live in such a dark time, is that she will make her heart tender to the Holy Spirit and that she'll submit to him, but that she'll stand against corruption and evil and darkness and use that steadfast spirit to stand for righteousness. But we're just entering the cuddly phase, and we're starting to see the gentle come out. So that's been really nice.

But one word that we choose to describe her quite often is we like to use the word passionate. She's very passionate about everything she does, and we like that word. That's the one that we've chosen to go with.
I love it. I love. Well, hey, she's being totally sweet right now, just with Mama and her YouTube.
Channel, and she's watching elephants and ducks. Who say Doc? Who say Doc? Oh, elephant. You're doing the trunk.
Oh, she's doing the trunk. Okay. I wondered why she. I thought she might just be pointing at the old man on the screen. But no, it's the elephant.
She does love to wave to everybody in Walmart and Kroger.

She's got a great smile. It. I love it. And, Eric, have you found that some of the fears, as we move toward wrapping it up, the fears you had about, well, parenting will look a little different for me. Have you found that's been okay? description_html:
“God is not above demolishing your hopes and dreams.” It’s a quote Eric Knox has not only uttered but lived.

An accident when he was a teenager left Eric permanently paralyzed. He wasn’t sure he could have children, or even whether he wanted to. But his wife Kendra felt the call to motherhood. And together, through Mini-Stim IVF, they discovered there is hope for spinal cord victims to become biological parents. They also learned that when God demolishes your dreams (and, in Eric’s case, fears as well), He’s ultimately bringing blessing, not devastation.

Eric & Kendra (and their daughter Eliana!) share their story in this episode of Hope, Faith, & Infertility. Here's the link: https://youtu.be/SQVze7VbGJE?si=3QM-7otZYXs6WgQL

Please rate, review, and subscribe wherever you listen to podcasts.

A full transcript is below (Please note this transcript was done by AI and may contain factual & grammatical errors):


00:01
Mark Mellinger
Well, there is hope for people who have spinal cord injuries when it comes to having children, and my guests today are living proof. Eric and Kendra Knox are with me here on hope, faith and Infertility, a podcast of Southeastern fertility in Knoxville, Tennessee. And their story is full of hope, encouragement, and definitely faith. So let's start here. Eric, we've had your wife on before. We haven't had you on before. I'm glad to have both of you here. So tell me about your spinal cord injury, how it happened and how it changed your life.


00:35
Eric Knox
Yeah, I was 15 years old and I was with a bunch of friends. We were in a big field that it was actually dug out for making a lake, but there had been no rain. And so were out there, boys being boys, doing donuts and throwing a ton of dust in the air and all that kind of fun stuff. And I was with a friend of mine riding shotgun, and we flipped the truck. It threw me out of the passenger side window, and then the truck rolled over me and you could imagine it was a pretty hard hit. So I'm just happy to be alive, really. But, yeah, I was conscious through the whole thing. It rolled over me right at the belly button area and so immediately just paralyzed me from the waist down or, well, from the belly button down.


01:25
Eric Knox

And everyone got pretty freaked out after that and we called an ambulance and it wasn't anything immediately that I thought was going to define the rest of my life. I thought it was going to be, I would get stuff back and then get back to life as usual, but that was not the case. But I've had a spinal cord injury, I'm a T ten paraplegic and have been so now for about 20 years.


02:02

Wow, interesting. You do remember it all. You weren't unconscious during this and you don't remember any pain?

There was no pain immediately. Initially, it was that huge surge of adrenaline that happeNed. I remember that. But after probably a couple of hours, I started realizing that my back was starting to ache, in which case it had been completely broken. Kendra Knox
We felt like God led us to enter a relationship, and so there's this moment where you're like, god, you've led us this far. And Eric was the first real, know, committed dating person that I'd ever had in my life. And so, like, this whole history of waiting for hi, baby. So anyways, were talking one day and I think I brought up the fear thing you did a little bit and was like, Eric, just, is there any way that you're not trusting God? 24:23
Eric Knox
No. All of those hopes and dreams that I had were not built on the foundation of Christ. They were built on the very wrong foundation, really?


24:33
Kendra Knox
Okay.


24:33
Eric Knox
And I was just going to say something that I wanted to add is a lot of times we mistake. In the world of Christianity, we mistake positivity for faith. Those are not like, man, if I believe hard enough, faith isn't believing something hard enough, even if it is like having kids is a very biblical thing. But just because you believe hard enough that it's going to happen, that's not faith. Our faith is in Christ alone and his accomplishment and what his will for our life is, which we don't know what it is exactly. We don't know if it's going to be to have no kids. One, two, three, who knows? And so our faith is in whatever it is that he has for us.


25:16
Kendra Knox
Just to balance all of that out. The goodness of God is very real.


25:21
Eric Knox
Absolutely.


25:21
Kendra Knox
And it's different than what we want. But for any believer who trusts in him, on the worst day, when we're dealing with finding out about the miscarriage, God's peace was there through that. And I don't know how unbelievers go through things like that without him. And there were so many moments throughout our whole journey that God gave us little, just glimmers of hope and who he is to kind of. Are you waving?


25:48
Mark Mellinger
I was going to say, and, yes, he does. He gives you those windows to help keep you going. So he's good in that respect. But for those of you who are watching the video version, you're seeing this beautiful little 16 month old, Eliana, who is their daughter, the result of their second transfer. And so we're going to talk about her a little bit again, beautiful little girl and a dream come true for you guys. So I want to hear about her. What's she like, and how has she changed your lives?


26:22
Kendra Knox
She's a Spitfire. Her name, first of all, Eliana Joy means God has answered because we had so many people praying for us, and joy because she brought us so much joy. And when were praying over her, when she was in the womb, I remember praying. We both got the word gentleness when were praying separately. Yeah, God's just calling us. I was praying the fruit of the spirit over my little tummy, and I prayed about gentleness, and I got three kicks, and it was the first time I felt her kick and I just thought, oh, the Lord's going to give us the most gentle child ever. It's a sign.


26:58
Eric Knox
And I was praying, too, and I was like, I don't know why, but I just feel like she's going to be a gentle soul. It was like that just resonated with me for some reason. And again, it was a feeling, so nothing that I can count on. But it was Od that both of us separately got the word gentle.


27:16
Kendra Knox
Well, and there's a scripture that says that a woman should have a gentle and quiet spirit, which is a great worth in sight. And I love that, because in today's culture, there's a lot of women that, of course, we have a voice, but you don't have to scream and shout and be rude. I wanted her to have a feminine spirit and the spirit that God created for her. And so we're praying gentleness. And, of course, this little one, she is a daredevil. She is one of the strongest little toddlers you have ever made. So I think God was preparing us. Okay, go ahead and start praying for gentleness.


27:53
Eric Knox
It was not an innate gentleness inside of her that God, maybe he was speaking to us, that. You guys are going to have to cultivate gentleness, this one, because she's not coming pre programmed with it. Keep that in the forefront of your mind.


28:08
Kendra Knox
It's a fruit of the spirit. And until she has the opportunity to choose Christ, that's how gentleness is being formed and created in her. But I will say she is one of the most determined little ones. And our prayer for her is, because I think we live in such a dark time, is that she will make her heart tender to the Holy Spirit and that she'll submit to him, but that she'll stand against corruption and evil and darkness and use that steadfast spirit to stand for righteousness. But we're just entering the cuddly phase, and we're starting to see the gentle come out. So that's been really nice.


28:44
Eric Knox
But one word that we choose to describe her quite often is we like to use the word passionate. She's very passionate about everything she does, and we like that word. That's the one that we've chosen to go with.


29:00
Mark Mellinger
I love it. I love. Well, hey, she's being totally sweet right now, just with Mama and her YouTube.


29:09
Kendra Knox
Channel, and she's watching elephants and ducks. Who say Doc? Who say Doc? Oh, elephant. You're doing the trunk.


29:15
Mark Mellinger
Oh, she's doing the trunk. Okay. I wondered why she. I thought she might just be pointing at the old man on the screen. But no, it's the elephant.


29:24
Kendra Knox
She does love to wave to everybody in Walmart and Kroger.


29:27
Mark Mellinger
She's got a great smile. It. I love it. And, Eric, have you found that some of the fears, as we move toward wrapping it up, the fears you had about, well, parenting will look a little different for me. Have you found that's been okay? Some of those things that you feared haven't been realized. You are able to do this more than you ever thought you would be able to.


29:54
Eric Knox
I guess I can say, so far so good.


29:57
Mark Mellinger
Yeah. A year and a half, right.


29:58
Kendra Knox
It's pretty early issue. And the just being a new dad.


30:02
Eric Knox
Yeah. I don't know if I can separate those two out, but it definitely is different just having to pick her up and she's down. She's up and she's down. And now that she's got two good legs underneath her, we don't have a very busy road. But there's always just that thought of, it's like a legitimate fear that you should have that you can't let your kid run out into the road. So I'm very vigilant about not letting her get close to the road or me staying between her or. I'm the dad who has the kid on the leash now.


30:43
Kendra Knox
We do. We bought a tether.


30:45
Eric Knox
Yeah.


30:46
Mark Mellinger
And why not?


30:48
Eric Knox
When you're as fast as you are, she's quick, too. So I just got to make sure that you really put a lot of forethought into planning for whatever you're going to go about your day and making sure that you have kind of safety in mind and all that type of stuff.


31:03
Kendra Knox
But you have adapted beautifully. I just have to say, I think other people at our church and just in the community watch you with her, and they're like, it looks like you haven't missed a beat.


31:14
Eric Knox
Well, all kids love going for a ride in a wheelchair, sitting in your lap. So all kids love that. I have random kids who will come up to me and climb up into my lap, like in Walmart, and they're just like, ride. All right, kid, let's go for a ride. Let's go find your mom and dad. Where they at?


31:30
Kendra Knox
Well, and just to emphasize how much we have enjoyed her, we're hoping to try again for another little one. So we'll be seeing you in a few months. We've been praying about a sibling for you to have. Yeah. Feel God's leading us to try again. So even though it's scary and we've been through it, we know what we're getting ourselves into. If the Lord calls you to this, he will equip you and he'll give you joy for the journey, too.


32:04
Mark Mellinger
He will. And, yeah, that's great, man. It would be great for you, too, to have another. Maybe that will be the gentle one. Or maybe you'll get two passionate kids.


32:15
Kendra Knox
Which is sleeper this time.


32:20
Mark Mellinger
Well, that was how it worked for us. Our daughter did not sleep at all, and then our son came a year and a half later, and we actually thought something was wrong with him. He was just a lump. The doctor's like, no, enjoy it. Yeah, maybe that'll be the case for you guys, too. So a couple last. You know, you are, for people who don't know, a radio host for American Family radio, you do a great show on there called Hannah's Heart where you're speaking to folks going through infertility from a. And, you know, you started out the show not being a mother a couple years ago, and now obviously you are. How has being a mother changed the way, if it has at all, that you approach your radio show? I don't know. Maybe it hasn't.


33:12
Kendra Knox
Yeah. Wow. Well, of course, you see just all the aspects of the goodness of God, and I think from a lot of the people that we've had on the program to share their story. One thing that I've come away with is that because I approached fertility with this, God doesn't owe me anything. This is the statistics in a very rational way. But we've got a little busy girl over here.


33:36
Eric Knox
No, that's fine.


33:37
Mark Mellinger
Eric can step out for a second.


33:40
Kendra Knox
God just showed me I can work however I want to work. And we've heard stories of miraculous conceptions, some people that were led to adoption, some people that heard about Southeastern and NEDC from our show and went and now have snowflake babies. So God doesn't seem to work the same way twice. So just being a host on the show has just really showed me having courage to hope, because when you have so much hurt and so much expectation that's not met. It's scary to hope. But just knowing that God is good and that you can trust that whatever his plan is for you, it is going to be good and you can lean into that. And thank you for mentioning the show. It's been so much fun. We've put this guy on.


34:28
Kendra Knox
We would love for any of your listeners to come join the Hannah's Heart family, and we'd love to pray for you guys while you're on your journey.


34:35
Mark Mellinger
Yeah. And it is a great show and you can find it at Hannah's Heart AFA on socials, and then you can find out how to listen there. It's on YouTube, so, yeah, it'll do your soul good. Definitely do it. Let's close with this. Do you all have any encouragement or advice, parting shots for other couples who are living with spinal cord injuries and sort of walking the same road that you did? Not sure what the future is going to look like, but want to have children?


35:09
Eric Knox
Yeah. Money is always a factor in this. Always. And so do your research. There's some simple, low cost options for you. And I would say start at the low cost option, try it, and then kind of work your way up. And that's what we did. And eventually we got to IVF, and that's really, like the only option. But do that maintain, like, pray together as a couple? That's what we still do. We pray together. We've already started praying over the second one. And wrap your minds around it might not happen. You don't know exactly what God's plan for your life is. And I know that sounds negative, but I have a spinal cord injury and I have more joy in my life than most able bodied people do.


36:00
Kendra Knox
You do.


36:00
Eric Knox
And it's because we go through the difficulty of when we pray to God, he already knows what your thoughts are. He knows what your fears are, so you might as well admit them to him. And you come in, you say, God, we want a kid and we want R1 bad, but we're scared it's not going to happen. And I have no clue what I'm going to do with myself if that's your answer, if your answer is like, no, kids aren't for you, or maybe it takes two or three tries and just be open with him, and it's very freeing to just admit that to him. He already knows it. And then a lot of times I think that might be what it is.


36:37
Eric Knox
You're just coming before him and just laying it all out there and letting him know, like, hey, I'm trusting you with this, and I'm going to be vulnerable with you about all of these fears that I have. And at the end of the day, I trust you with whatever your answer is, whether it's a kid on the first try, the third try, or moving on from IVF and trying adoption, or maybe some sort of an alternate means of parenthood and fatherhood, but do that together. Pray as a couple. And just lay it all out there before him and in front of each other, too.


37:11
Mark Mellinger
So good. Yeah. Then that's real prayer, too. I really appreciate that. And we will be praying for you two and actually you three as you come back here. So, Eric, Kendra, Eliana, my guest today. So appreciate your story and how God has worked in your life. And you're absolutely right. Whatever he has for you can trust him with the bigger picture and you are really living proof of that. We want to thank you for joining us. If you want more information about Southeastern fertility, you can go to the website southeasternfertility.org. Southeasternfertility.org. Maybe you'd like a free 15 minutes consult. Dr. John David Gordon does provide those. Absolutely no charge. Get some new eyes on your situation and a lot more you can check out there. I'm Mark Millinger. This has been hope, faith and infertility.

To schedule your free 15-minute telemedicine consult with Medical Director Dr. John Gordon, call 865-777-0088 or click here. To learn more about Southeastern Fertility, including our mission, values and team, click here. To learn more about IVF with Southeastern Fertility, click here.

content.text: In this deep and rich hour-long episode of the Hope, Faith, & Infertility podcast, Rachel & Rollin unpack the intense soul struggles their infertility exposed.
Hear how God brought each of them to a new level of surrender as they worked to embrace the notion that He only writes good stories.
You'll find their journey packed with practical takeaways. Here's the link:
A full transcript is below (Please note this transcript was done by AI and may contain factual & grammatical errors):

So I want to invite you into a conversation today with a couple who came all the way from several states away to do business with southeastern fertility. A long, infertility journey as well, almost a decade. Rachel and roland mays are my guests here on the hope faith and infertility podcast, coming to you from southeastern fertility in knoxville, tennessee. Southeastern
. For more information, I'm mark Mellinger, your host. So let's start here. Talk about when you two got married was infertility a thought for you back then.

So I think when we first got know, based on my personality, I kind of always imagined worst case scenarios because we had been married for about four years when we started trying to get pregnant. And I remember there was that thought that crossed into my head about, what if it takes a long time or what if we can't? And so I'm just going to keep sharing my journey. But kind of that first year, there was always this sense of, I think I would reason with myself, like, oh, sometimes it takes a year. And so kind of like, holding out with this hope of it would happen eventually. And then I remember once we hit the one year mark, went and saw my doctor to talk about it, and I think that's when it really sunk in, like, this is not happening. And I know for me, I can struggle with wanting control, and I have more of, like, anxious personality.

And so there was kind of this dynamic in me coming out of I was very fearful and had this desire to kind of try and like, okay, well, let's just control things. Let's figure it out. Let's make it happen. And so let me see. We went to see my doctor, and then she recommended us to see a fertility specialist, and then we kind of went to one locally and kind of started pursuing fertility treatment. And then kind of what happened is I think we both realized weren't really on the same page. I think I kind of realized I was kind of doing this out of control anxiety. And I know roland can kind of share where he was at in a few minutes, but I remember kind of hitting this point of realizing we just didn't feel peace to keep going in pursuing fertility treatment, and so we kind of just paused on that.

So this is back in 2015. So it was like about a year into our journey, and I think at that point, I kind of really went through just a season of deep grief and mourning and kind of like asking those questions like, god, where are you? I really struggled feeling abandoned. So I think what was actually happening is it was actually god's kindness was probably just revealing some deeper questions I had towards god of like, wait, does he see me? Is he with me? And so kind of like 2015 to 2016 was kind of a year of really wrestling with the Lord and kind of, I think just like, grieving and just feeling just the pain of, like, this is not happening. I think also in that season in our church, in our community, we probably saw there's probably at least five couples that were peers with us all get pregnant, and then we're just kind of here, like, okay, this is not happening.

We don't know what. And I think in that space, I really struggled feeling pretty isolated. If you've walked through infertility, you kind of understand there's, like, something about it that you feel really ashamed if you haven't gone through. It's hard to understand, but there's something that I don't know what it is, but I know I really struggled feeling, like, a sense of shame and, like, a loneliness and isolation and kind of what happened was in the summer of 2016. So now we're two years into kind of just this road, and were actually spending the summer in Colorado with kind of part of our jobs. We were kind of helping run a summer discipleship program for college students. And I remember getting to a point in my relationship with God where I just kind of came to a point of surrender, of just really asking Him if this is not going to happen, if this is something we need to let go, can you just tell us?

I think kind of just coming to that point of like, yeah, if we need to let this go, I'll do it. And kind of through it's kind of hard to explain, but just through just different things that happened. I really felt this sense in my heart, like, just this impression from God. He was basically encouraging me to not stop asking for it. And I kind of really felt like he told us that we would have biological children, which is kind of a scary thing of like, wait, how do you learn that? And then how do you walk that out? But I really felt like almost like he was saying, I want you to keep asking. Like, don't stop hoping for it. And I think in that moment and there were other things that happened where I don't know how to explain it, but I think I really just had just this moment or just series of moments of understanding and really believing.

Like, wait, god was with me in it that I struggled to feel like forgotten, but for somehow I knew deep down he was with us. He saw us. He was doing something. We couldn't understand what was happening, but he was moving in it. And I just remember that just totally changed the game for me. And I remember from that point on, there was no guarantee moving forward. It's like, okay, I really felt like God impressed this on my heart, but I don't know what's going to happen. But I knew he was very good. I just remember moving forward, just really believing, whatever happens, he's really good to us, and I can trust him. And so then it became this, I think, a journey of what does it mean to kind of, I think, persevere in prayer. I came back from that summer kind of with two things, this sense of to keep praying for it.

And then I also really felt this sense of wanting to just invite people into this journey with us. I really felt like God was calling me to radical vulnerability and transparency, I think, out of this place of just feeling like, man, I don't want to let this isolate me and Roland. And so that was kind of a turning point in just really telling a lot of our friends and family, like, we're walking through this, will you pray with us? And so it kind of became a journey since 2016 of just walking with our friends and family, them just kind of praying for us and just kind of engaging with how were doing in it. And I think there's this tension in my heart of really praying boldly and continue to persevere and at the same time be really surrendered in it because there was no guarantee.

Even though I kind of felt this sense like this was what God was calling us to do. It's like, well, it could not happen. I could be wrong. And coming to a point of if I was wrong or if we never have children, it's okay. Like, coming to a place of really being able to believe and see that, okay, God is like, enough for us. He's going to take care of us. He's like the real reward in this life. And so in that there was kind of this freedom of like, man, I'm going to go for it and be bold with the Lord and continuing to ask and believe, but then also be content with kind of where were at.

And that is, I think, really instructive. Rachel, that is not a place that everybody who is encountering infertility gets to, or anybody who's going through any sort of major life trial gets to. But as a believer, I think you have to get to that place where you say, there is this thing that I want, and it seems like a good desire, and I want God to give it to me. I'm going to ask. My impression is that he also wants the same thing. And that's why I laughed a little bit when you were telling your story. Sometimes when Christians think God has spoken to them, that just can't be questioned in their minds. I know you're not saying it like that. You held it with a very open, humble hand. We can't always be sure our impressions from God are 100% correct, but nonetheless, that's what you felt, and it seemed to make sense, but yet you were willing to say if this never happened.
I can put it on the cross and I can accept somehow, as hard as it seems, that what God has for me is better for me. Ultimately.

And I love how you said he's the reward, the relationship with him is the reward. And I want to dive into that a little bit later because that's also a truth that a lot of Christians are eluded by, and we all can be there sometimes when life wears us down. But Roland, I'm interested in hearing from your perspective. She mentioned that you guys were on different pages at first.

Yeah, well, it's interesting, I didn't think about this coming into this podcast, but when you asked us that question, my mind actually went back all the way to 2008, which is when Rachel and I met, and we met as students at the same summer discipleship program that she referenced in 2016. That later in 2016, were staffing in the context of our college ministry.

I should mention, by the way, that you guys do college ministry down in Texas. I said at the beginning, you came from several states away, I didn't say where. So Texas. Yeah. Nobody loves their state like a Texan.

Yeah, that's right. What's really crazy in our story is that the first serious conversation that Rachel and I ever had was centered around Isaiah 54. And I was really obsessed with Isaiah 54 at that time. And the first line of Isaiah 54 is, sing, o barren woman, says sing, obarren woman, who has not born. And then there's just this incredible series of promises out of that. It's like, for the children of the desolate, one will be more than the children of her, who is, you know, God was speaking that to the nation of the even specifically, like the city of Jerusalem, which was like this mother of the family of God that had yeah, desolated as a result of the exile and sin. Well, really, as a student, what had caught my heart with that passage was this idea that God was saying basically to sing out of the very place where you feel cursed and lost.

And I remember talking Rachel's ear off about that because that idea is like a paradigm for life. Like, how can I take the area where I feel cursed or lost and respond to it by breaking forth and joyful singing? That's what the Isaiah 54, it's like a command. Sing obaran woman. So that passage ended up being read at our wedding and our officiate, his little sermonette, Rachel's older brother, was based on Isaiah 54. And I had always thought of that in a very again, almost like a paradigm for thinking about life. The specifics of being barren were not something that I anticipated once that became part of our story. Actually, that passage at times to me felt almost like a cruel irony, like a trick that God had played on us that we'd kind of been brought together because we would still say it's like it's in some ways our passage.

It's a very significant thing, even the context of our marriage, and I really wrestled with that, of my sense of the character of God and the goodness of God, almost like, did you set us up for this? Whereas Rachel, she mentioned that her tendency might be toward control, mine can be toward passivity. And so my way of dealing with difficult things in life is to kind of have a roll with the punches, mindset and attitude. Like, I know difficult things are going to happen. I'm not going to ignore or deny that they're difficult, but I'm not going to try to fight them or sort of overcome them. I'm just going to kind of accept this is how it is. And so when we started experiencing infertility, that was my very strong instinctive response. It was painful and scary, but for me, the easiest way to deal with that was just to kind of say, okay, this is just reality.

Let's not fight it. And Rachel described how went through this process of kind of starting to pursue taking some initial steps towards getting help with fertility. And what ended up stopping us is that I came to a point where I realized, wait, I'm not actually present in this. I'm almost just doing this because Rachel wants to do it. And it's not coming out of a unified place in our marriage where we're together feeling a sense before the Lord of like, yes, this is what we want to do. We have freedom to do, or he's inviting us to do it, however you want to phrase it. I just realized I was just kind of along for the ride and that was wrong. I couldn't just be along for the ride.

So freeze it for just a second. I want to stop you. You can continue in a second because I want to hear it, but I just want to camp out on this for a second. Infertility is so hard on marriages, and I'm trying to envision this in my mind's eye. Did this cause first of all, you're trying to be a good husband, and you've got a wife who's very concerned about this, so you got to hold that at the same time, you're not feeling what she's feeling. Like, you said you didn't feel like you were a part of it. This was her dream, not yours. I'm putting words in your mouth, but something to that effect. Did this cause significant conflict in your marriage?

Well, I think it's kind of interesting. It's almost like because I chose to be passive, it was more of like conflict avoidant than conflict engaged. It was like I deeply wanted to be a father. I mean, I had felt that desire. I remember in high school, I would say this thing like, I remember telling my parents, I want to have four to eight kids. You'll find their journey packed with practical takeaways. Here's the link: https://youtu.be/aAjprdWab7k?si=CzVWW1UrrkOAHns7

A full transcript is below (Please note this transcript was done by AI and may contain factual & grammatical errors):

Rachel Mayes

Yeah, sure, to some degree, it's going to be that way. A little bit touch and go for the next six months. But things are looking good now, and we're going to hope and believe for you guys as well. And I don't know that I've done one of these where there were more helpful takeaways. I think this is really going to help a lot of believers who are going through the same sorts of trials that god has had for you. So just want to thank you two so much, and please know we're going to be praying for you back here in knoxville and cannot wait to see a picture of that baby.

01:01:41

Thank you.

Thank you.

We appreciate y'all well, if this has.

content.text: Is it okay to be mad at God? How can peoples’ words be so insensitive? What bad news is coming next?

These were all complex questions Sam & Hayley wrestled with amid their infertility, some of which they faced while Sam was going through cancer treatment. But by sharing their suffering, they were able to help others- and themselves. Even when their faith felt flimsy, they had a support network believing for them.
Meet them and their twin boys in this Hope, Faith, & Infertility podcast episode packed with helpful takeaways! Here's the link:

You better not get pregnant and leave. That's all I'm saying. Linda's not going to be happy about that if that happens.
Tell me about where you're from. A little bit. Just about general background.

I grew up in a little town, long Beach, Mississippi, much smaller than long Beach, California. I moved to Memphis my senior year of high school, so came into Tennessee and then went to UT after that, and I've been in Knoxville ever since. Love it.
Did you go to UT in Memphis or you come here to actually go?
Cool. So you loved it. Love it. Yeah. It's a neat place to be in. Yeah.
I feel like you're in the mountains. You also have access to the beach.
Screen, the lakes, all kinds of lakes around here. Tell me about when you graduated nursing school and what you've done since then before coming down.

So, I actually went to LMU for nursing school. I did, like, an accelerated program. My first job out of school was on anti partum postpartum floor in the hospital. We basically took care of high risk pregnancies. If their water broke early, we'd keep them until they delivered.
After that, I went to the NICU for and did that, and now I'm here.
What was your favorite or your best liked area of working in the hospital? Was it one or the other of those? And I probably say NICU.
I just love working with the babies, so that part I will definitely miss.
Show me with your hands what the tiniest baby that you've taken care of.
I mean, some of them can literally sit in your palm.
Oh, wow. That is so amazing. That is amazing that they can keep those babies alive till they catch up. Yeah.
Modern medicine has changed everything about the NICU.

Well, I happened to be in the NICU area once upon a time, not working, but I had to go up and get something from one of the nurses in the same place that you worked. I remember the walls were painted with all kinds of neat kids stuff, and it was just a beautiful place. They did a really good job. On that, and I think that's neat.
So when you worked antipartum, is that.

Yeah. How long did you keep your longest patient that you can remember or one of the patients that was on that floor? How long before? From the time they come in with the water breath till they delivered.

I can't remember exactly. I know we had one that came in at 23 weeks. She was really 26. Come in the next day, and I want to say she held on until maybe 32 weeks. So quite a long time. You get the best relationship with those patients. You see them every two, 3 hours.

I'm sure they were lucky to have you.

We got it on camera. You heard her. She's going to be her permanent.

I'm mean, you are not mean. That's for darn sure. If anybody around here is mean, it ain't you.
I got to ask you, are you an old Miss Fan or a UT fan.
Okay. Well, then I guess you do fit in pretty well around Knoxville. That's great. Well, welcome. Now, are you going to be helping with the NADC folks at all, or is it just southeastern.
Okay, so our NADC folks may see you around, but you won't actually be helping with them. Okay, well, good to know. It's great to have you here.
Unless me and Burke are built out, and then it's all you, girl.

Did this morning I did see the most beautiful rainbow? Everybody came in with pictures on their phones. I have to admit, I barely made it here at eight, but I was on time. Dr. Gordon right, at eight, because I had to stop and pull over next to the lake where they love the boats down in off of Concord. Or is that North Shore?
That's North Shore. It's North Shore, but I know where you're talking about. Yeah.
I got the prettiest picture of the rainbow with all the colors reflecting on the lake. I'm going to have Mark post it just because we're getting in betas and a lot of positives.
Oh, good. Glad to hear it.
The rainbow to me this morning is just like there's a promise, there's hope, and it's just neat.
Yeah, a lot of rainbow babies. We hope and pray.

Indefinitely. Okay, so we'll count on 50 years. Your contract's waiting in the next room.

content.text: It's about time- it, being this video!

Whenever you're pursuing fertility treatment, patience and time are two unavoidable elements. So much of the process is outside of your control, which means the ideal timetable you had in mind at the start rarely plays out.
So how do you set realistic expectations? Even more importantly, how do you avoid getting so tripped up by the time element that it complicates your process?

Southeastern Fertility Medical Director Dr. John David Gordon and IVF Coordinator Lynda McCollum have some timely (pun totally intended) insights to make your journey more pleasant and, hopefully, increase your chance of success!
To schedule your free 15-minute telemedicine consult with Medical Director Dr. John Gordon, call 865-777-0088 or
. To learn more about Southeastern Fertility, including our mission, values and team,
To learn more about IVF with Southeastern Fertility,

content.text: As partners on a medical helicopter team, Heather & Marty became experts at saving lives. But one life that couldn’t be saved was that of Marty’s teenage son.

Yet his memory lives on years later through Knox, the Southeastern Fertility baby to whom Heather just gave birth. It’s a beautiful story of perseverance and faith anchored by a special Scripture verse; a verse that kept pointing Heather & Marty to hope, even when they were told having a child was impossible.
Be inspired and equipped by the Season Two debut episode of our podcast Hope, Faith, & Infertility. Here's the link to the video version of the podcast:

content.text: Curious about the potential benefits of reproductive acupuncture? Then you’ve come to the right place.
Potential benefits include increased blood flow to the part of the body that needs it when trying to establish pregnancy, stress relief, and more.
There are also eye-opening statistics to share about the correlation between reproductive acupuncture and positive pregnancy results.
Our friend Sarah Prater from Tennessee Center for Reproductive Acupuncture joins Southeastern Fertility’s Mark Mellinger and Lynda McCollum for this video to talk all things reproductive acupuncture!

content.text: When it comes to IVF, failure isn’t necessarily final. Something valuable can always be learned.
When IVF is unsuccessful, the failure will generally come down to one of three factors: the transfer itself, the lining of the uterus, or the embryo(s).
Reviewing the attempt with your physician is a valuable experience because it gives you and the doctor the chance to explore important questions related to those factors.
Some of those questions could include:
Were there difficulties accompanying the transfer?
Was there inflammation in the lining?
How did the body respond to medication or stimulation?
Unpacking the answers to these and other questions can go a long way toward impacting how (and whether) you move forward with more treatment in the future. The lessons learned can give you real hope.
Southeastern Fertility Co-Director Dr. John Gordon and IVF Coordinator Lynda McCollum have more in this video, originally posted on social media as part of our popular “Facebook Friday” series.

content.text: Charity & Rhett went through a long road of infertility over several years. Along the way, they navigated failed IUIs, surgery, unsuccessful IVF, a very iffy positive pregnancy test, and even an ice storm! But amid their pain and vulnerability, they also discovered an amazing support system in their local church. And yes, eventually, they welcomed the son for whom they had so long prayed.
Learn from and be encouraged by this Southeastern Fertility family’s wonderful story in this episode of our “Hope, Faith, & Infertility” podcast.
Rate, review, and subscribe to “Hope, Faith, & Infertility” wherever you listen to podcasts.

content.text: Dominique & Tim didn’t know it was possible to have a child, then experience infertility. But that’s exactly what happened to them. In this episode of our “Hope, Faith, & Infertility” podcast (below), Dominique explains how secondary infertility challenged (and ultimately strengthened) her faith, how Mini-Stim IVF proved to be her family’s answer, and how she managed to go through it all while simultaneously pursuing advanced education.
Rate, review, and subscribe to “Hope, Faith, & Infertility” wherever you listen to podcasts.

content.text: Infertility is so hard to bear. Yet, seen through the eyes of faith, it can become redemptive. Jacob & Beth say the lessons they learned through infertility and the premature births of their twins prepared them to deal with other, longer-term trials in life. Through it all, they’ve come to trust God more and learned to serve others well. Be inspired by their journey by looking up this episode of Southeastern Fertility’s “Hope, Faith, & Infertility” podcast.

content.text: Alyssa and Jonathan’s infertility journey was far from easy. Yet it ultimately grew their faith and reaffirmed they could entrust themselves to God’s loving care.
In this episode of our podcast “Hope, Faith & Infertility” below, learn how an IUI led them to the gift of their second son Waylon, finally giving big brother Jimmy a sibling.
Alyssa felt so good about her experience with Southeastern Fertility, she even ended up joining the team!

content.text: Could eating pineapple really help your embryo implant? What about wolfing down some french fries from Mickey D’s? We’re looking into those fertility-related superstitions (and many more) in the brief video below. Here are some helpful time stamps:
Can going to the bathroom after a transfer make you lose the embryo? What about getting into a car wreck?
Can taking a home pregnancy test before you get a blood test lead to a negative pregnancy attempt?
Can eating pineapple help your embryo implant?
Does eating McDonald’s french fries help promote successful embryo implantation?
Is loading up with water going to help lead to a successful transfer? What about acupuncture?
Should you have intercourse the night before a transfer?
Is it okay to shower after an embryo transfer?
Can you get on a plane after an embryo transfer?
Will eating and drinking exclusively warm food and beverages affect your embryo transfer?

content.text: When Andre and Jessica got married, they were blending two families. Next came the faith-testing challenge of trying to have a child together. In this episode of our Hope, Faith & Infertility podcast below, learn about their journey and how Southeastern Fertility was privileged to come alongside them. This couple has enjoyed great success in business and athletics -Andre was actually a member of the legendary 1998 Tennessee Volunteers national championship football team!- but they say welcoming Tyson to their family tops it all.

content.text: Erin used to dream she had triplets and woke up considering those dreams to be nightmares. She didn’t think there was any way she could parent so many kids at once. It took actually having triplets for her to realize she was wrong. In this episode of our Hope, Faith & Infertility podcast below, Erin -now a mother of four- unpacks her journey with host Mark Mellinger. Find out how she and her husband navigated infertility, the vital role her faith played, and even get some helpful tips on resources for moms raising multiples.
Rate, review and subscribe to Hope, Faith & Infertility wherever you listen to podcasts.

content.text: At Southeastern Fertility, we believe in the power of prayer. Families going through trials are on our hearts constantly, and we’re genuinely praying for them regularly.

Have you ever wondered how we pray for those walking through failed embryo transfers or pregnancy losses? How about for those who, conversely, are celebrating or hoping for positive results? In the video below, you’re invited to find out, and of course to join us as we bring our families before the Lord.

content.text: Southeastern Fertility Co-Director Dr. John Gordon and IVF Coordinator Lynda McCollum, as you’ll see in the video below, are cozying up next to the fire to talk about why people from all over the country (and even some foreign countries!) are willing to come all the way to Knoxville to build their families.

It boils down to this: When it comes to embryo adoption, thanks to our exclusive partnership with the National Embryo Donation Center, we have an incomparable number of embryos onsite right here in our lab. And almost all are remaining from successful IVF! In a nutshell, this is where the embryos are!

But there are other reasons people from hundreds or thousands of miles away turn to Southeastern Fertility. Some may want lower-cost IVF without all the usual fertility medications, in which case we offer affordable alternatives like Natural Cycle IVF and Mini-Stim IVF.
Still others may just be seeking advice on battling infertility from a listening ear, in which case Dr. Gordon offers free 15-minute telemedicine consultations.
To schedule your free 15-minute telemedicine consult with Co-Director Dr. John Gordon, call 865-777-0088 or
. To learn more about Southeastern Fertility, including our mission, values and team,
To learn more about IVF with Southeastern Fertility,

content.text: Control: It’s something we all want, but in actuality none of us totally has, especially when it comes to battling infertility. But at Southeastern Fertility, you always have a prayer!

It is our medical team’s high privilege to pray with and for you during your infertility treatment if you so desire. We believe strongly in the power of prayer, while also deeply respecting your own personal convictions and desires. That means you can rest assured you’ll never be pressured into prayer or anything else with which you might be uncomfortable.
In the video below, Southeastern Fertility Co-Director Dr. John Gordon and IVF Coordinator Lynda McCollum unpack our approach a little further.

content.text: Over the past few years, the genetic testing of embryos prior to transfer has become a more common practice in reproductive medicine. But we don’t do it at Southeastern Fertility. Why, you ask?

The simple answer is that the leadership team considers it a slippery slope. Southeastern Fertility Co-Director Dr. John Gordon, alongside IVF Coordinator Lynda McCollum, explains why in the video below.

content.text: Tom Petty was right. The waiting is the hardest part!

That’s certainly true when it comes to fertility treatment. Patients often anticipate taking part in a particular transfer cycle, only to endure the disappointment of finding out they’ll need to wait another month.

If results aren’t back from pre-transfer medical tests, it’s vital that physicians and patients not just jump right into an embryo transfer in order to stick to a certain schedule. Test results must be examined to determine whether the patient is in optimal health, which in turn leads to the best chances of a successful transfer.

Cysts, failure to stimulate, and numerous other reasons could cause a transfer cycle to be delayed as well. In this video, Southeastern Fertility Co-Director Dr. John Gordon and IVF Coordinator Lynda McCollum advise that while this is frustrating, decisions to delay a cycle are made with patients’ best interests in mind.

content.text: Unlike Olympian Katie Ledecky, there are times in IVF when swimming ahead of the competition isn’t a good thing!

For instance, when it comes to baseline ultrasounds for Mini-Stim IVF or Stimulated Cycle IVF (in which multiple eggs is the goal), it’s not good to see one follicle “swimming ahead” of the others. Those other follicles can be left behind and fail to grow. Suppression is a necessary step in these cases, or else the cycle may not yield the hoped-for results.
Natural Cycle IVF, on the other hand, is a different story. In that situation, multiple eggs is not the goal, so “swimming ahead” isn’t problematic.
Southeastern Fertility Co-Director Dr. John Gordon and IVF Coordinator Lynda McCollum have more in a short video at the link below.

content.text: Life has its share of setbacks and disappointments. Unfortunately, cancellations or delays of embryo transfer cycles during fertility treatment can sometimes be among those unpleasant hiccups.
There can be many reasons for cancelling the embryo transfer portion of a cycle, including:
-A woman’s body is unresponsive to the medical protocol.
-A fibroid or polyp develops and needs to be removed.
-The uterine lining just doesn’t develop properly.
-A woman’s body is overly responsive to the medical protocol.

But if any of these happen to you, all hope is not lost. A successful transfer cycle may still be very possible, and could be just ahead in the near future. Southeastern Fertility Co-Director Dr. John Gordon and IVF Coordinator Lynda McCollum unpack all of this in detail in this video.

description_html:
Life has its share of setbacks and disappointments. Unfortunately, cancellations or delays of embryo transfer cycles during fertility treatment can sometimes be among those unpleasant hiccups.

There can be many reasons for cancelling the embryo transfer portion of a cycle, including:

-A woman’s body is unresponsive to the medical protocol.

-A fibroid or polyp develops and needs to be removed.

-The uterine lining just doesn’t develop properly.

-A woman’s body is overly responsive to the medical protocol.

But if any of these happen to you, all hope is not lost. A successful transfer cycle may still be very possible, and could be just ahead in the near future. Southeastern Fertility Co-Director Dr. John Gordon and IVF Coordinator Lynda McCollum unpack all of this in detail in this video.

To schedule your free 15-minute telemedicine consult with Co-Director Dr. John Gordon, call 865-777-0088 or click here. To learn more about Southeastern Fertility, including our mission, values and team, click here. To learn more about IVF with Southeastern Fertility, click here.

content.text: In the normal course of reproduction, an embryo makes its way into the uterus on Day 5. It then usually attaches and implants on Day 7. However, when it comes to IVF and frozen embryo transfers, it’s actually possible to “cheat the system”- and it still works!

Southeastern Fertility Co-Director Dr. John Gordon and IVF Coordinator Lynda McCollum explain, with their trademark brand of fun thrown in, in this video. By the way, what do you think of Dr. Gordon’s new Management Resolution Device?!
